Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Role of Surplus Production in the Emergence of a Complex Coastal Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Surplus production is often linked to social development and the rise of politically complex societies. It has historically been thought to help people buffer risks. Largely, however, past work has focused on agricultural societies, with fewer studies considering how surpluses were produced and managed under other economic systems. With support from the National Science Foundation, Drs. William Marquardt, Victor Thompson, and Michael Savarese will conduct research at the Mound Key and Pineland archaeological sites to investigate the role of surplus production among the Calusa of southwest Florida, who were the most powerful group in peninsular Florida in the sixteenth century A.D. The Calusa king collected tribute from a population in excess of 20,000 distributed among 50 to 60 Calusa communities extending from the northern reaches of Charlotte Harbor to the Florida Keys. However, unlike the farming people of the interior river valleys of the southeastern U.S., the Calusa relied primarily on fish and shellfish for protein, collecting wild plant foods and using only a handful of plants from home gardens. Most importantly, they did not grow maize, which formed the basis of surplus production and political complexity for many groups across the Southeast. This project focuses on surplus production and distribution in a complex fisher-gatherer-hunter society. Few archaeologists have examined surplus production among fisher-gatherer-hunters, especially those in the sub-tropics. This research will shed light on long-term sustainability of fisheries, a topic of considerable world-wide interest, and address the potential impact of over-harvesting shellfish. The project will also help train the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists, both undergraduate and graduate students. As part of the research, the team will teach a field school that will involve students drawn from a broad geographical region. Students will be trained in research, as well as specialized methods and traditional archaeological excavation. The research will bring students with interests in archaeology, geology, and ecology together to address a burgeoning field in geoscience: conservation paleobiology (applying the theories and analytical tools of paleontology to solving problems concerning the conservation of biodiversity). The project will also partner with the Florida Public Archaeology Network as well as the Randell Research Center to engage the public throughout the research process.

Specifically, by means of coring and archaeological excavations in structures thought to be fish and shellfish storage and processing features, the team will examine how the Calusa produced and managed large-scale food surpluses presumed to be necessary to sustain their large populations. This work aims to discover how surplus production was situated within the larger histories of the Calusa, and how these practices structured interactions with Europeans. This work will serve as a comparative study against examples that focus on the links between surplus, storage, social development, and the transition to agriculture and animal husbandry. Development of comparative case studies such as this one will help disengage the concepts of surplus, storage, and social relations in terms of both individual agency and collective action.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two critical prerequisites must be met for a coastally dependent society to become and to remain successful. First, resources must be plentiful to ensure the population can be sustained and to allow the free time for society to culturally flourish (i.e., a surplus economy). Second, the environment must remain hospitable for biologic productivity and not be subjected to drastic changes due to climate fluctuation. For a coastal society, at least for one that does not practice agriculture, this means having plentiful marine and estuarine resources (fin- and shellfish) for easy gathering and a stable sea level to prevent drastic alterations in estuarine ecology and geography. The Calusa Native Americans that existed in Southwest Florida from AD 1000 to 16thcentury AD were in such a situation. They engendered a politically and socially complex society, while existing as a hunter-gatherer-fishing people. They also exploited an estuarine environment, whose existence depended upon a slow but steady rise in sea level. This project, representing a collaboration among archaeologists and geologists, investigated the Calusa?s potential for maintaining a surplus economy and the paleoenvironmental context that predisposed that economy. Though this was a study of human history, the work is relevant to the planet?s contention with the effects of future climate change. Accelerated sea-level rise, as a consequence of global warming, is poised to grossly influence coastal geography and estuarine ecology, and is likely to harm current coastal surplus economies.

Archaeological excavations and geological sediment coring on Mound Key, the political center for the Calusa kingdom, and in Mound Key?s neighboring estuary of Estero Bay have revealed the following:

The Calusa manufactured mounds composed of shell refuse, principally oysters, that were harvested for consumption, rather than collected as cultch for building material. Taphonomic characteristics (i.e., the preservational state of shells), typically employed in paleontology, of the interior surfaces of shells composing the mounds are near pristine, suggesting the animals were collected live, eaten, and then repurposed for building. In contrast, dead shells collected from modern oyster reefs in neighboring Estero Bay have poorly preserved shell interiors. Shells left exposed subtidally after death become substrate for bioencrustation and corrosion. Given the volume of oyster shell and their pristine preservational state, oysters were clearly a staple of the Calusa diet.

Large expanses of productive oyster reefs currently occur within what would have been a short canoe paddle for the Calusa inhabiting Mound Key. Sediment cores taken from these reefs exhibit productive oyster reef habitat dating back to at least 1000 yBP. An abundant oyster fishery was therefore available to the Calusa through their period of cultural development.

A series of rectangular landforms exists around the perimeter of Mound Key, each with raised berms enclosing areas of lower elevation that are commonly flooded during high tide. Sediment cores from these features and archaeological excavations along the berms indicate these ?water courts? functioned as enclosable storage facilities for finfish. Sediments from the water court cores contain abundant fish elements, skeletal materials that are rarely found in sediments from the estuarine bays. The ability to easily harvest a plentiful shellfishery and to store finfish, coupled with the Calusa?s practices of smoking fish, facilitated their surplus economy without reliance upon agriculture.

Long cores from modern oyster reefs neighboring Mound Key exhibit an ecological succession from more marine-influenced bioconstructions dominated by vermetiform gastropods (of little food value) to more brackish water reefs constructed by oysters. The period of gastropod reef construction (from ~2800 to 1000 yBP) predates the timing of Calusa arrival and their subsequent cultural development in the region. Oyster-dominated reef construction began ~1000 yBP, coinciding well with the Calusa?s arrival on the landscape. This transition in water quality and ecology represents the onset of estuary development and the timing of the bay?s enclosure through the development of seaward barrier islands. Cores taken from behind the current barrier islands denote a similar timing of island development, occurring ~2900 yBP. Barrier island formation and the development of the estuarine ecology in the islands? wake require a slow rate of sea-level rise of no more than 1 mm/year. Consequently, the estuarine conditions necessary to support productivity to fuel the Calusa?s surplus economy were highly dependent upon a narrow range of climatic and sea level conditions. The time for exploitation of the abundant resources was ideal for the Calusa?s cultural development.

Currently, the acceleration of sea-level rise rate is causing the incipient degradation of estuarine conditions. This is indicated by increased erosion rates of barrier islands and greater marine water ill-influence on oyster reef productivity (admittedly further exacerbated by society?s current practices of freshwater management). Modern society in Southwest Florida, critically dependent on a coastal tourism and sport fishing economy, is at risk due to the degradation of the environmental conditions that the Calusa first exploited.
